_prev_prog_3.Description: All 2-methylpropene handling, safety, and countermeasure equipment are covered under an extensive test and inspection program, and under the plant?s preventive maintenance program. The outlets of the storage tanks and the railcars are protected by excess flow valves that close tight if their set point is exceeded. The storage tanks, railcar unloading, reactor, and compressor areas have perimeter or process flammable gas detectors. There is a leak detection and repair program that calls for the inspection and gas testing of valves, pumps, and compressors. There are water curtains that are activated by high LELs around the storage, reactor, compressor, and unloading areas. High LEL readings in these areas will also activate the Zone 1 E-stop.  The Zone 1 E-stop shuts down all isobutylene equipment and closes automatic valves on the storage vessels and railcar unloading areas.  The Zone 1 E-stop can also be manually activated by operators from 3 areas within the plant. There are heat activated foam deluge systems over any area where the 2-methylpropene is handled. The majority of 2-methylpropene liquid and vapor unloading and vessel piping and gaskets have been upgraded to 300 psig rated equipment and include thermal expansion relief valves that discharge to the flare header system.  The first piping flanges on the storage tanks have been upgraded with double-seal, high performance, leak resistant Change gaskets.  The liquid automatic shutoff valves have been moved to the first flange position. All personnel who operate or maintain equipment, or manage the process in an area where 2-methylpropene is handled are trained on safe handling techniques, countermeasures for leaks, how the fire systems work, and what to do in case of fire or leak. There is a management of change program.  All 2-methylpropene areas fall under the plant?s 29 CFR 1910.119 compliance program.  All other safety programs apply. There are parts of the transfer lines that are not inside of the detection perimeter or under the deluge systems, but they are in the leak detection and repair program and are protected by excess flow valves, and all other prevention programs apply.  Two additional LEL sensors have been added to the area below the isobutylene recovery piping.  High LEL levels from these sensors will activate the Zone 1 E-stop.  All LEL sensor systems will provide radio warning alarms at pre-determined levels to alert personnel to potential releases.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Sasol Chemicals (USA) LLC's

Isobutylene (2 methylpropene)

Risk Management Program Executive Summary



Accident Release Prevention and Emergency Programs



The Oil City Plant's Risk Management Plan Program provides a systematic approach to prevent the accidental release of chemicals to the environment. This is accomplished through both engineering and administrative controls. All applicable elements of the U. S. EPA's Prevention Program and OSHA's Process Safety Management standard are adhered to. The Oil City Plant's Emergency Plan is tailored to meet the needs of any foreseeable release and was developed using input from the local emergency response agencies (Cornplanter Township Volunteer Fire Department, Oil City Fire Department, and Venango County Emergency Management Agency). The plan was submitted and approved by the Venango County, PA Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC).



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled



The Oil City Plant is a manufacturing facility that produces Butylated Hydroxy Toluene (BHT), a crystalline Phenolic antioxidant and m-cresol, a chemical intermediate. Isobutylene (2-methylpropene) is stored in bulk at the plant, and is used to add the butyl groups onto mixed cresols (methylphenol). The isobutylene storage tanks and associated transfer equipment have several engineered safety features such as:  internal and external excess flow valves; perimeter monitor, alarm, and shutdown interlock systems; pressure relief valves; a flare protected vent system; and administrative procedures to prevent or detect releases. The plant is manned 24 hours a day and the isobutylene system is monitored continuously. There are automated vapor dispersing, fire extinguishing, and associated alarm systems around the isobutylene storage, reactor, compressor, and off-loading areas. All storage and handling equipment as well as all safety and countermeasure equipment are on a rigid testing and inspection program as well as a general preven

tive maintenance program.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Prevention Steps



The general accidental release prevention program includes but is not limited to the following elements.



1) Safety training for employees who operate, inspect, or repair the isobutylene handling equipment.



2) Unit specific procedures for operating, trouble shooting, and maintaining the isobutylene handling equipment.



3) A comprehensive preventive maintenance and mechanical integrity program to insure the safety and reliability of the isobutylene handling equipment.



4) A leak detection and repair (LDAR) program to detect leaking valves and pump seals.



5) Perimeter gas monitoring systems at the storage, reactor, and off-loading areas that are tied into automatic alarms, shutdown interlocks, water curtains, and water/foam deluge systems.



6) A process gas monitoring system at the spent gas compressors and associated equipment that is tied into automatic alarms, shutdown interlocks, and a water deluge system.



7) A process gas monitoring system below the 2-methylpropene recovery transfer piping that is tied into automatic alarms, shutdown interlocks, and a water/foam deluge system.



8) An emergency vent flare system to relieve any excess pressure that could occur.



9) A management of change program.



10) A Process Safety Management (PSM) System developed to be in compliance with OSHA's PSM standard(29CFR1910.119).



Five Year Accident History



There have been no accidental releases of isobutylene within the last five years that meet the criteria of reporting in "Air Programs, Part 68, Subpart B, 68.42".



Emergency Response Program



The Oil City Plant has a comprehensive emergency contingency program, which has been reviewed by the Venango county EMA and the local responding fire departments (Cornplanter Township and Oil City), and has been approved by the Venango County Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC). The Oil City Plant does not

have an emergency response team for fire response, but all operations and maintenance employees are trained at the 24-hour technician level for hazardous material spills and clean- up. Oil City Plant personnel have been trained how to activate countermeasures and notify emergency response agencies. They have been trained how to assess the situation and communicate to emergency response personnel the most prudent course of action to take to safeguard the community. Oil City Plant management personnel will report to work on site with emergency responders as a resource for controlling releases of isobutylene, and for operating counter measure systems. Oil City Plant personnel will assist the Incident Commander on the scene as specialists in handling isobutylene. The emergency plan is reviewed and resubmitted to the Venango County LEPC when updated for its review and approval. Necessary elements of the plan are incorporated into the Venango County Emergency Response Plan.  Periodic tabletop or deployment drills are conducted to keep emergency response personnel familiar with plant materials, emergency systems, and response measures.



Recent Changes to Improve Safety



The Oil City Plant performs periodic process hazard analyses (safety reviews) of all chemical processes, including the isobutylene system. Some of the recently completed changes to improve the safety of the isobutylene storage and transfer system are listed below.



1) The dealkylation reactor V-2220 was replaced in-kind as the previous vessel was reaching its end-of-service life.



2) The first piping flanges on the storage tanks have been upgraded with double-seal, high performance, leak resistant Change gaskets.  The liquid automatic shutoff valves have been moved to the first flange position.



3) High pressure alarms and interlocks have been added to V-2220.



4) An Emergency Response Quick Reference Guide has been developed to aid external emergency responders in the event of a release inciden

t.



5) A railroad unloading vent system was modified to include a nitrogen purge to prevent freezing under winter conditions.



The Oil City Plant has a continuous improvement philosophy in all safety and environment issues.
